benchmark_details.name: Emotion Reasoning as a Theory of Mind Benchmark for Large Language Models
benchmark_details.overview: This study advances beyond surface-level perceptual features to investigate how large language models (LLMs) reason about others’ emotional states using contextual information, within a Theory-of-Mind (ToM) framework, by curating a specialized ToM evaluation dataset to assess both forward reasoning—from context to emotion—and backward reasoning—from emotion to inferred context.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate how well LLMs can engage in both forward and backward emotion reasoning.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: This study investigates emotion reasoning within a constrained context —the Prisoner’s Dilemma game.

data.source: Curated vignettes derived from psychological decision-making frameworks.
data.size: 582 vignettes total (432 for forward reasoning, 150 for backward reasoning)
data.annotation: Manual annotation with theoretical grounding in cognitive appraisal theory.

methods: Evaluation against Theory of Mind tasks
methodology.calculation: Accuracy calculated based on how well LLMs predict the correct emotional states or appraisals.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy reflects better reasoned emotional inference by LLMs.
methodology.baseline_results: Gemma 7B achieved an accuracy score of 57.9% on the forward reasoning task.
methodology.validation: Training validations were based on systematic manipulation of emotional appraisals in provided vignettes.

targeted_risks.harm: Potential misinference of emotional states leading to misunderstandings in applications.
